metadata.titleEn: Multi-frequency and multi-angular ground-based microwave radiometer and surface parameters experimental data for cropland in 2017
metadata.description:
This data set was collected in summer 2017 during the ground-based microwave radiometry experiment, which is part of the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River (SMELR). The experiment site is located in Duolun County, Inner Mongolia (116.47°E, 42.18°N, at 1269 m in altitude). The data set contains three parts, namely brightness temperature data, soil data and vegetation data. The microwave brightness temperature data was observed by a vehicle-mounted dual-polarized multi-frequency radiometer (RPG-6CH-DP), including the horizontal (H) and vertical (V) polarization brightness temperatures at L-, C- and X-bands. The brightness temperature data were acquired from 30° to 65° with an interval of 2.5°, and the time resolution is 0.5 hours. Soil data contains 5 layers of soil moisture and soil temperature (2.5 cm, 10 cm, 20 cm, 30 cm, 50 cm) over three croplands (corn, oats, and buckwheat), with sampling intervals of 10 minutes. The soil data also contains soil surface roughness, rainfall, irrigation flags, and soil texture. Vegetation data contains leaf area index, plant height, vegetation water content, etc.
The experimental period lasted from July 19 to August 30, 2017, and it provided important data for the land surface microwave radiation modeling and validation, as well as the development of soil moisture retrieval algorithms.
metadata.instructions:
The data file is saved in xlsx format and is named as: DuolunExp+ '_ParaName'. 'ParaName' represents the abbreviation of the observed parameter. For example, the brightness temperature is named as 'DuolunExp_TB.xlsx', the soil data set is named as 'DuolunExp_Soil.xlsx' and the vegetation data is named as 'DuolunExp_Veg.xlsx'. 
Data reading method: The data set can be directly opened  with Excel.

background: Soil moisture (SM) is a vital variable in hydrological, biological and geochemical processes, and it plays an important role in energy exchange between land surfaces and the atmosphere. Eﬃcient SM monitoring can support various applications, such as crop growth monitoring, drought assessment, flood warning, evaporation estimation, and numerical weather forecasting. Unlike traditional manual in situ measurements, passive microwave remote sensing has a great advantage in estimating the surface SM at a global or regional scale. Among the diﬀerent wavelengths of microwave sensors, L-band radiometry is one of the most eﬀective techniques for monitoring the SM due to its proper penetration into vegetation and soil layers. Currently, satellites carrying the L-band radiometer include the Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity (SMOS) mission and the Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) mission. The SMOS mission launched in November 2009 is the first mission to map global SM by using L-band observations. SMOS has multi-angular observation capability, which can provide more information about surface microwave radiation. The SMAP mission was launched in January 2015, which incorporated a radar and a radiometer. The mission concept is to combine the complementary attributions of the radar and radiometer observations to enhance the resolution of SM.
research objective: With the new development of potential satellite missions, it is important to evaluate existing soil moisture retrieval algorithms, which will greatly contribute to the improvement of current soil moisture products and the development of new methodologies. This paper compared the performance of four well-known soil moisture retrieval algorithms with L-band radiometry at fixed incidence angles, including the single channel algorithm at horizontal polarization (SCA-H), the single channel algorithm at vertical polarization (SCA-V), the dual channel algorithm (DCA), and the land parameter retrieval model (LPRM).
challenges: The results showed that the retrieval accuracy of the SCA-H and SCA-V is significantly affected by the input vegetation optical depth, and the calibration of vegetation parameters should be considered in the implementation of the SCA-H and SCA-V. However, its retrieval requires a penalty on parameter constraints since the input brightness temperatures at horizontal and vertical polarization are correlated. The LPRM has a poor performance at incidence angles less than 30°, as it analytically utilizes the polarization difference in the brightness temperature, which is quite small at lower incidence angles.
methods: The experimental data used for evaluation was from the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River (SMELR), which consists of variable angular ground-based and airborne observations covering a wide range of incidence angles (22.5°–55°) at L-band. The microwave radiative transfer models are set to be consistent to guarantee that the four different algorithms are comparable.
dataset: The experimental data used for evaluation was from the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River (SMELR), which consists of variable angular ground-based and airborne observations covering a wide range of incidence angles (22.5°–55°) at L-band.
findings: The results showed that the retrieval accuracy of the SCA-H and SCA-V is significantly affected by the input vegetation optical depth, and the calibration of vegetation parameters should be considered in the implementation of the SCA-H and SCA-V. The DCA does not rely on the auxiliary vegetation information and can also achieve good performance for both the soil moisture and vegetation optical depth. The accuracy of four soil moisture algorithms achieve their best performances at intermediate incidence angles of 40° to 45°, and is slightly degraded when the incident angles increased to larger than 50°, which is contributed to the increasing vegetation effects and depolarization that leads to an information loss. These findings provide quantitative evidence to help understand the differences in various current soil moisture algorithms and further promote the development of new methodologies for future soil moisture missions.

background: Due to the success of the SMOS (Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity) and SMAP (Soil Moisture Active Passive) missions, new satellite missions are on the horizon. The current and future missions can benefit from investigations that seek to improve retrieval algorithms that quantitatively map global soil moisture and vegetation optical depth (tau) from Earth’s microwave emissions.
research objective: In this study, we explore multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches for the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation tau, considering the payload configurations of current and future satellite missions (such as the Copernicus Imaging Microwave Radiometer, the Water Cycle Observation Mission, and the Terrestrial Water Resources Satellite) using a new set of ground observations.
challenges: It is affirmed that increasing the number of observation channels could make the soil moisture retrieval more robust, but might also limit the retrieval performance, as the probability that the model estimations will not match the observations is increased.
methods: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) are used for this study. A multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is developed based on the two-component version of the omega-tau model, which utilizes information from collaborative channels expressed as an analytical form of brightness temperature at the core channel to rule out the parameters to be retrieved.
dataset: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) are used for this study.
findings: Results of soil moisture retrieval show that the multi-angular approach used by the MCCA generally has a better performance, unbiased root mean square difference (ubRMSD) varying from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.037 cm³/cm³, than the multi-frequency approach (ubRMSD from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.089 cm³/cm³) for the corn field. Except for in the C- & X-band combination, the multi-frequency approach used by the MCCA performs better (ubRMSD from 0.018 cm³/cm³ to 0.023 cm³/cm³) than the multi-angular version (ubRMSD from 0.026 cm³/cm³ to 0.034 cm³/cm³) for the grass field due to reduced vegetation effects for this type of cover. This study provides new insights into the design of potential satellite missions to improve soil moisture retrieval. A satellite with simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observation capabilities is highly recommended.

Definition.Question: What is the concept of 'soil moisture retrieval algorithms' and how are they used in the context of this field?
Definition.Answer: Soil moisture retrieval algorithms are computational methods used to infer soil moisture content from microwave remote sensing data. These algorithms analyze brightness temperature measurements collected by radiometers and utilize different models to estimate soil moisture levels. They are critical for interpreting satellite observations and improving the accuracy of soil moisture mapping on a global scale.

Definition.Question: What does 'L-band radiometry' mean in the context of remote sensing for soil moisture monitoring?
Definition.Answer: L-band radiometry refers to the use of microwave sensors that operate in the L-band frequency range (1-2 GHz) to observe and measure natural microwave emissions from the Earth's surface. In soil moisture monitoring, L-band is preferred due to its effective penetration through vegetation and soil layers, allowing for more accurate soil moisture estimations even in areas with moderate vegetation cover.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when using multi-frequency approaches compared to multi-angular approaches in soil moisture retrieval from microwave emissions?
Comparison.Answer: The multi-frequency approach may offer more data channels to improve robustness but can face challenges due to model estimation mismatches with observations, potentially limiting retrieval performance. The multi-angular approach, on the other hand, generally performs better for certain crop types by providing a range of incidence angles, which can help mitigate vegetation effects and depolarization issues that affect information retrieval.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying principles can be inferred about the effectiveness of multi-frequency and multi-angular microwave radiometry in soil moisture retrieval, considering different vegetation types?
Interpretation.Answer: The multi-angular approach tends to perform better in corn fields, likely due to the ability to capture variations across angles, while the multi-frequency approach shows improved results in grass fields, indicating that the frequency range can mitigate vegetation effects. This suggests that soil moisture retrieval may benefit from adapting strategies based on vegetation type and using a combination of angles and frequencies to optimize results.

Interpretation.Question: How do variations in observation angles impact the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval algorithms, and what could this imply about the choice of angles in designing future retrieval models?
Interpretation.Answer: Retrieval accuracy is optimal at intermediate incidence angles (40° to 45°) but decreases at angles over 50°, likely due to increasing vegetation effects and depolarization. This indicates that future models should consider optimizing observation angles to balance the need for capturing sufficient surface information while minimizing confounding factors like vegetation interference.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges do the calibration of vegetation optical depth and brightness temperature correlation present in soil moisture retrieval, and how might these challenges inform improvements in retrieval methodologies?
Interpretation.Answer: The need for calibration of vegetation parameters affects retrieval algorithms like SCA-H and SCA-V, while the correlation between horizontally and vertically polarized brightness temperatures imposes constraints. Addressing these challenges could involve developing methods to decouple vegetation effects and refine calibration processes, thus enhancing retrieval accuracy and robustness.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of accurately retrieving soil moisture using microwave radiometry in agricultural fields?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The retrieval accuracy of soil moisture using microwave radiometry in agricultural fields is significantly affected by the input vegetation optical depth. Calibration of vegetation parameters should be considered due to their influence on the retrieval process. Additionally, the correlation between brightness temperatures at horizontal and vertical polarizations can require penalties on parameter constraints, affecting accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might increasing the number of observation channels in microwave radiometry not always enhance the performance of soil moisture retrieval?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: While increasing the number of observation channels could make soil moisture retrieval more robust by providing additional data, it might also limit retrieval performance. This is because the probability that model estimations will not match the observations increases with additional channels, potentially complicating the retrieval process and reducing accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes variability in the performance of soil moisture retrieval algorithms across different incidence angles?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The performance of soil moisture retrieval algorithms varies across different incidence angles due to factors such as vegetation effects and depolarization. These factors can lead to information loss at larger incidence angles. The accuracy of the algorithms is generally better at intermediate angles of 40° to 45°, while performance tends to degrade at angles larger than 50°.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of incorporating multiple angular observations into soil moisture retrieval algorithms using microwave radiometry?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of multiple angular observations allows for improved retrieval accuracy of soil moisture by providing more comprehensive information about surface microwave radiation. It was found that the accuracy of soil moisture algorithms is best at intermediate incidence angles of 40° to 45°, enhancing the performance by reducing vegetation effects and depolarization that can cause information loss at larger angles.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of multi-frequency channels affect the robustness and performance of soil moisture retrieval from microwave emissions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating multi-frequency channels makes soil moisture retrieval more robust by providing additional data points, although it may also increase the difficulty of matching model estimations with observations. The study found that for certain types of vegetation cover, like grass fields, the multi-frequency approach generally outperformed the multi-angular approach due to reduced vegetation effects.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise from using ground-based microwave radiometry datasets for evaluating soil moisture retrieval algorithms in different environmental conditions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing ground-based microwave radiometry datasets enables the assessment of different soil moisture retrieval algorithms across varied environmental conditions, leading to a better understanding of their performance and limitations. This approach provides quantitative evidence that can support the development of new methodologies and improve current soil moisture products, particularly by highlighting the effects of various incidence angles and vegetation types on retrieval accuracy.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary intention behind utilizing multi-frequency and multi-angular ground-based microwave radiometry in soil moisture studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary intention is to improve the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval by taking advantage of the different characteristics of microwave frequencies and angles, which can enhance understanding and development of soil moisture retrieval algorithms and ultimately contribute to better soil moisture products and methodologies.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop and evaluate multiple soil moisture retrieval algorithms using L-band radiometry?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to develop and evaluate multiple soil moisture retrieval algorithms using L-band radiometry because it helps assess their performance under various conditions, leading to improvements in current soil moisture products and the development of new methodologies, which are crucial for upcoming satellite missions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to collect and process multi-frequency multi-angle ground-based microwave radiometer data for soil moisture and vegetation studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves using a ground-based microwave radiometer, such as the RPG-6CH-DP, to capture brightness temperatures at different microwave bands (L, C, and X) and polarizations (horizontal and vertical) over a range of incidence angles (30° to 65°) with a temporal resolution of 0.5 hours. The data processing includes monitoring soil moisture and temperature across five soil layers, as well as gathering additional surface roughness, rainfall, irrigation, and soil texture information. Vegetation data such as leaf area index and plant height are also recorded.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the performance of soil moisture retrieval algorithms evaluated using ground-based observations from microwave radiometry datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The performance of soil moisture retrieval algorithms is evaluated by comparing different algorithms such as SCA-H, SCA-V, DCA, and LPRM using L-band radiometry data. The evaluation involves analyzing the retrieval accuracy across various incidence angles and assessing the impact of vegetation optical depth. This process is supported by consistent microwave radiative transfer models that ensure comparability and calibration of vegetation parameters for algorithm implementation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches are used to enhance soil moisture retrieval accuracy from multi-angular and multi-frequency microwave observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To enhance soil moisture retrieval accuracy, a multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is utilized, which incorporates multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches based on the omega-tau model. This method leverages information from multiple observation channels to analytically process brightness temperature data and reduce vegetation effects. The MCCA approach is noted for its better performance in certain field conditions, such as corn and grass fields, by effectively managing the different impacts of vegetation cover on microwave emissions.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the use of passive microwave remote sensing to estimate surface soil moisture at a regional scale?
Enablement.Answer: Passive microwave remote sensing, particularly L-band radiometry, enables efficient estimation of surface soil moisture at a regional scale. This technique benefits from proper penetration into vegetation and soil layers, providing advantages over traditional manual measurements. The Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity (SMOS) mission and the Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) mission are examples of satellites utilizing L-band radiometry, offering multi-angular observation capabilities to enhance soil moisture retrieval.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are associated with calibrating vegetation parameters in soil moisture retrieval algorithms using microwave radiometry?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges in calibrating vegetation parameters in soil moisture retrieval algorithms arise from the significant effect of vegetation optical depth on retrieval accuracy. Algorithms such as the single channel algorithm at horizontal and vertical polarizations (SCA-H and SCA-V) require careful calibration of vegetation parameters to mitigate the impact on the accuracy of soil moisture estimates. These challenges necessitate penalty constraints to account for the correlation between horizontal and vertical polarization brightness temperatures.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise from increasing the number of observation channels in soil moisture retrieval algorithms?
Expectation.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels could make retrievals more robust but also potentially limit performance. This is because the probability that model estimations will not match observations might increase, indicating that a balance must be found between robustness and retrieval accuracy.

Expectation.Question: Why might the retrieval accuracy of soil moisture algorithms degrade at larger incidence angles?
Expectation.Answer: The accuracy of soil moisture algorithms tends to degrade at larger incidence angles due to increasing vegetation effects and depolarization, which leads to information loss. This suggests that intermediate incidence angles might provide a more optimal balance for accurate retrievals.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of ground-based microwave radiometry data collection methods in improving soil moisture retrieval algorithms?
Judgmental.Answer: Ground-based microwave radiometry data collection methods are effective in improving soil moisture retrieval algorithms as they allow for the evaluation of different algorithms using variable angular observations. This method provides valuable insights into the performance of retrieval algorithms, especially in understanding the effects of vegetation optical depth and the optimal incidence angles for accurate soil moisture estimation.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the main challenges associated with using multi-frequency approaches for soil moisture data collection, and how might they impact the accuracy of retrieval algorithms?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges associated with multi-frequency approaches include the potential limitations in retrieval performance due to an increased number of observation channels. This can lead to model estimation inconsistencies with observations. However, for certain types of land cover, such as grass fields, multi-frequency approaches can reduce vegetation effects and enhance retrieval accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how multi-angular observations improve the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval algorithms.
Assertion.Answer: Multi-angular observations provide more information about surface microwave radiation, as they capture the brightness temperature at different incidence angles. This approach helps in understanding the effects of vegetation and soil layers on microwave emissions, leading to improved retrieval accuracy for soil moisture algorithms.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure why increasing the number of observation channels might limit the retrieval performance of soil moisture.
Assertion.Answer: While additional observation channels can enhance the robustness of soil moisture retrieval, they may also increase the complexity of the model. This complexity can lead to discrepancies between model estimations and observations, potentially limiting the retrieval performance.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how ground-based microwave radiometry datasets contribute to the development of new satellite missions for soil moisture monitoring.
Assertion.Answer: Ground-based microwave radiometry datasets provide valuable insights into the behavior of microwave emissions from soil and vegetation under various conditions. This data is crucial for evaluating and refining soil moisture retrieval algorithms, which ultimately aids in the design and improvement of new satellite missions aimed at global soil moisture monitoring.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the key methodologies for collecting multi-angular and multi-frequency microwave radiometry data in agricultural settings.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies involve using ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected with multi-frequency and multi-angular capabilities, as demonstrated in the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River. The data collection includes monitoring at different incidence angles and frequencies, utilizing microwave radiometers to capture brightness temperature across L, C, and X bands for various crops.
